fields.value: Replication data for: Are African Party Systems Different?

dsDescriptionValue.value: Recently Mozaffar et al. [Mozaffar, S., Scarritt, J.R., Galaich, G., 2003. Electoral institutions, ethnopolitical cleavages and party systems in Africaâ€™s emerging democracies. American Political Science Review 97, 379e390] presented evidence suggesting that African party systems are somehow different from party systems elsewhere in the world. In doing so, they promoted the common notion of African exceptionalism. We believe that their conclusions are open to question because they draw inferences from a number of multiplicative interaction models in which they do not include all constitutive terms, interpret constitutive terms as unconditional marginal effects, and fail to calculate marginal effects and standard errors over a sufficiently large range of their modifying variables. By correcting these practices, we reach substantively different conclusions. Specifically, we find that African party systems respond to institutional and sociological factors such as district magnitude and ethnic fragmentation in the same way as party systems in more established democracies.

publicationCitation.value: Thomas Brambor, William Clark, Matt Golder. 2007. "Are African Party Systems Different?" Electoral Studies 26: 315-323. article available here

files.description: The paper only shows our analysis for legislative parties. Substantiating our claim in footnote 2, this file shows that our claims hold when using electoral parties as the dependent variable as well.

files.description: This do-file essentially replicates everything that we do using STATA_mozaffar.dta concerning electoral parties with the more correct dataset golder1.dta. It also presents a number of graphs explicating the interactive relationships of the variables.

files.description: Creates Figure 1 indicating the effect of ethnic fragmentation on the effective number of electoral and legislative parties using MSG's data (left graph) and the corrected data from Golder (2005) with recoded concentration scores. Specifically, those countries that were coded as having  concentration=0 but which had exactly one ethnic group were recoded as having a concentration score of 3. This do-file then creates the figure indicating the effect of ethnic fragmentation now
files.label: Fragmentationfig_FIG1.do

dataFile.description: Creates Figure 1 indicating the effect of ethnic fragmentation on the effective number of electoral and legislative parties using MSG's data (left graph) and the corrected data from Golder (2005) with recoded concentration scores. This do-file then creates the figure indicating the effect of ethnic fragmentation now

files.description: Mozaffar et al. make some claims in footnote 7 of their article that ethnic fragmentation independently reduces the number of parties if we specify an unconditional model.  We reject these claims.  This file provides the results of our attempts to replicate their claims. This test is referred to on page 5 of our article
files.label: Unconditionalfragmentation.do

dataFile.description: Mozaffar et al. make some claims in footnote 7 of their article that ethnic fragmentation independently reduces the number of parties if we specify an unconditional model.  We reject these claims.  This file provides the results of our attempts to replicate their claims. This test is referred to on page 5 of our article
